article.title: Fast kNN mode seeking clustering applied to active learning

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the time complexity of the original kNN mode seeking algorithm (MS)?
What is the primary advantage of the fast kNN mode seeking algorithm (FMS) over the original MS algorithm?
choices: FMS requires less memory to store data.
FMS has a lower time complexity, making it faster, especially for large datasets.
FMS can be used for unsupervised and supervised learning tasks.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the "complexity parameter" (c) in the FMS algorithm?
choices: It controls the maximum number of clusters that can be found.
It determines the trade-off between speed and accuracy by adjusting the size of Q-cells.
It sets the maximum number of iterations for the clustering process.
It defines the distance metric used for calculating distances between data points.

multiple_choice_question.text: Based on the experimental results in the paper, which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the performance of active learning with kNN mode seeking?
choices: Classifiers trained on modal objects selected by kNN mode seeking generally perform worse than those trained on randomly selected objects.
Combining classification results from different clustering levels (multi-level clustering) often leads to worse classification performance.
kMeans consistently outperforms MS and FMS in active learning scenarios.
Active learning with kNN mode seeking can be significantly more effective than using randomly selected training data, especially when labeled data is scarce.
